newsitem.title: UK: Metals end mostly firmer, LME still ranging.
newsitem.headline: Metals end mostly firmer, LME still ranging.

text.p: Base metal prices largely trended higher during Thursday LME trading, although the pace of business was mostly routine with prices generally rangebound, traders said.
Copper, which was successfully supported at $2,300 on Wednesday, consistently pushed higher but stalled at intermediate resistance around $2,350.
News that unions at Poland's KGHM were on strike alert was supportive, but did not over-exite the market which is still ranging between $2,320/30 and $2,380 on the upside.
At the end of the kerb three months prices were at $2,351.50, up $26.50 a tonne from Wednesday. The cash/threes backwardation widened to around $39/44, against $36.
Aluminium prices were firmer, partly helped by copper, but also bouyed by short-covering after Wednesday's support at $1,650.
The market was also helped by a headline drop in February IPAI daily production, although some analysts doubted the veracity of recent data which now includes Chinese figures.
Angus MacMillan of LME trader Billiton Metals Ltd noted that the IPAI data suggested that overall Asian production had fallen.
However, China's State Statistical Bureau said today that China production in Jan/Feb rose 23.5 percent.
"The implication is that IPAI production fell elsewhere in Asia," he said.
But output elsewhere in the region is being maintained, so the data that has been added this year to the IPAI is increasingly suspect.
By the close of the kerb prices were $16 steadier at $1,669 - well above the early low of $1,650.
Nickel prices perked up during the session, also helped by trends in copper, with the market edging back above $8,000. Last trade was at $8,040, up $55 from the previous kerb.
Lead and zinc were both steadier throughout the session although the former metal drifted back towards the lower end of the day's range on the kerb to close at $694, up just $3.
However, zinc remained reasonablly well supported above $1,300 and poised to test recent 4-1/2 year highs. The market closed at $1,305, up $9.
Tin bucked the trend, with the market swinging back into a contango after this week's backwardation proved short-lived. Last trade was at $6,025, down $10.
Alloy was quoted at a steadier $1,553/1,555 a tonne.
